children.text: Okay, I need to translate this Java code to C. Let me first understand what the Java code is doing. The code reads an integer n from input.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Then, it initializes two arrays h and g, each of size n. It reads n pairs of integers, storing them in h and g.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Then, for each element in h, it checks how many times it appears in the g array, summing up all those occurrences. Finally, it prints the total count. So, in C, I need to replicate this behavior. Let's think about the steps. First, reading the input. In Java, they use Scanner, but in C, I'll use scanf. The first input is n, which is straightforward. Then, for each of the n lines, read two integers into h[i] and g[i].
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Wait, the original Java code uses sc.nextLine() after nextInt() might have issues, but looking at the code: the Java code reads n via nextLine(), then uses nextInt() in a loop.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Wait, actually, in the Java code, after reading n with nextLine(), then for each i from 0 to n-1, it reads h[i] and g[i] via nextInt(). But in Java, nextInt() leaves the newline in the buffer.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: However, since each pair is on a separate line, perhaps the input is provided such that each h[i] and g[i] are on the same line, separated by whitespace. So the Scanner's nextInt() will handle that correctly. In C, reading n can be done with scanf("%d", &n).
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: Then, loop n times, each time reading two integers into h[i] and g[i]. So in C, I'll need to declare the arrays h and g. But since n is read at runtime, in C99 or using a compiler that supports variable-length arrays (VLA), I can declare them as int h[n], g[n].
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Alternatively, if VLAs are not allowed, perhaps use dynamic allocation with malloc. But for simplicity, assuming the code can use VLA. Then, the nested loops: for each i and j, if h[i] == g[j], increment result. That's straightforward.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text:
Putting it all together:

Read n.

Allocate arrays h and g of size n.

Loop i from 0 to n-1, read h[i] and g[i]. Initialize result to 0. Loop i from 0 to n-1, loop j from 0 to n-1, check if h[i] == g[j], increment result. Print result.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Potential issues:

In C, when reading input with scanf, if the input is not properly formatted, it might lead to issues. But assuming the input is correct as per the problem's requirements.
